author: ajsutton
content:
Block times on eth1 are quite highly variant. Anything that assumes about 13 second block times is likely already broken anyway. 
The only thing I can think of is if a contract was intended to lock some funds up until a point in time and then inexplicably decided when that time is based on the block number instead of time stamp. But even then the contract is doing exactly what the original code intended so I canâ€™t see how it could be considered broken.

author: sky.cactus
content: The security community and core devs have been telling people to use block.timestamp for long term times since forever.  I don't feel bad for people who didn't listen.
